risinfo.chaptertitle: 21. Interviewing Individuals at Risk for Suicide

sect1.title: Summary
sect1.para: Given the significant rise in suicide rates in recent decades, evidence-based, suicide-focused assessments and interventions are crucial for reducing suffering and mitigating suicidal behavior. The process of gathering information during assessment can follow structured or semi-structured approaches—though, we advocate for an integrated approach utilizing actuarial assessments and open-ended questions examining evidence-based suicide risk factor domains. Numerous actuarial assessment measures have been developed, but those demonstrating the most robust evidence include the ASQ, C-SSRS, BSSI, PHQ-9, and SITBI, all of which are mentioned and discussed earlier in this chapter. Regardless of validated tools, suicide risk assessments are anxiety-inducing. Clinicians across all practice settings should prioritize leading with a balanced, empathetic, and patient-centered approach to ensure an accurate formulation—thereafter management—of their patients’ suicide risk. Likewise, special attention is needed when caring for vulnerable populations, such as youths and those from culturally and racially diverse backgrounds, given their well-documented rising suicide rates. Some key elements in assessing for suicide risk are to gather where an individual falls on the ideation-to-action pathway, taking into consideration lifetime history of SITBs, stressors specific to their age, and the influence of sociocultural factors. Most suicide risk assessments are a single snapshot of an individual’s suicide risk at a given time. Rather than prioritizing rigid classifications and measurement tools, clinicians are recommended to take a flexible yet consistent approach to accurately capture an individual’s suicidality and its dynamic nature.
